prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Reasons for Protection of Confidential Information

head.headtext: Disadvantages of Protection of the Exclusive Use of Ideas

para.paratext: Society is only prepared to pay for practical results. As such, protection of the exclusive use of ideas does not directly reward the innovator but does so indirectly from the ability to use the innovation to obtain profits from the marketplace.[1] Vaver suggests that there ought to be a special sort of protection for the theorist.[2] This “theory patent” might allow other theorists to build on the knowledge revealed, but would require those applying the idea to pay the creator of the idea a proportion of their revenues based on the extent to which the original theory contributed to their application.

The idea of economic or commercial value of the application or expression of an idea stems from the theory of intellectual property. Vaver states that this logic, as applied to confidential business information, contains a number of flaws:

The logic flowing from a concept of natural rights, that ideas should be protected in perpetuity and throughout the world, has never been accepted by even the most ardent promoters of a strict intellectual property regime. Nor, if social reward is the criterion, can we say exactly what services deserve what reward. Does a pulp novelist read by millions merit as much as the inventor of insulin, even if readers are shown to need the pulp for their sustenance as much as a diabetic needs insulin to survive?[3]

It has also been argued that there is little from a practical point of view that can be done to stop copying and borrowing using new technological equipment such as photocopiers and video and tape recorders. However, the problem of enforcement can and should be overcome in the same way that other systemic problems are dealt with: by enforcing criminal or civil laws to minimize the problem.

A more difficult dilemma is the balancing of the property rights of those who own confidential information against the lives of those who require the benefit of these new discoveries for survival.[4] This latter criticism fails to take into account the public policy consideration to which all property rights, both real and intellectual, are subject.

It may also be problematic for a judge with little or no technical expertise to determine the merits of complex technical innovations. As a result, the equitable remedies of unfair competition and unconscionability used to protect confidential business information frequently result in divergent and unpredictable decisions.[5] It may be preferable to have a panel of judges specifically trained to deal with intellectual property issues (as there is in Britain). However, the courts would seem an appropriate forum to deal with the balancing of the rights to an idea with public policy concerns because courts have the flexibility and required power to enforce a right if necessary.
F. Scherer, Industrial Market Structure and Economic Performance (Chicago: Rand McNally, 1970), pp. 382-94.
D. Vaver, “Intellectual Property Today: Of Myths and Paradoxes” (1990), 69 Can. Bar Rev. 98 at p. 126.
D. Vaver, “Intellectual Property Today: Of Myths and Paradoxes” (1990), 69 Can. Bar Rev. 98 at pp. 99-100.
B. McLachlin, “Intellectual Property: What's It All About?” in G.F. Henderson, ed., Trade-Marks Law of Canada (Scarborough: Carswell, 1993).

See Schering Chemicals Ltd. v. Falkman Ltd., [1982] Q.B. 1 (C.A.), where the majority considered the breach of confidential information as “a flagrant breach of an elementary duty to honour confidences”. Lord Denning in dissent held that it would be unfair to accuse the confidant of a flagrant breach because the disclosures were in the public interest. See also Deta Nominees Pty. Ltd. v. Viscount Plastic Products Ltd., [1979] V.R. 167 (S.C.), at p. 189, where Lord Denning held that there was no breach of confidence while the majority held that “the conscience of a recipient or possessor of information [was] so affected as to make it ‘unconscionable’ on his part to publish or use the information”.
